Standards:

* CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RL.3.1: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
* CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RL.3.2: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
* CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RL.3.3: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
* CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RI.3.1: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
* CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RI.3.2: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
* CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RI.3.3: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
* CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RF.3.4: Read with sufficient accuracy and fluency to support comprehension.
* CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RF.3.4.A: Read grade-level text with purpose and understanding.
* CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RF.3.4.B: Read grade-level prose and poetry orally with accuracy, appropriate rate, and expression on successive readings.
* CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RF.3.4.C: Use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, rereading as necessary.

These standards come from the Common Core State Standards for English Language Arts and Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects.

Citations:

* Common Core State Standards Initiative. (2010). English Language Arts Standards: Reading: Literature: Grade 3. <http://www.corestandards.org/ELA-Literacy/RL/3/>
* Common Core State Standards Initiative. (2010). English Language Arts Standards: Reading: Informational Text: Grade 3. <http://www.corestandards.org/ELA-Literacy/RI/3/>
* Common Core State Standards Initiative. (2010). English Language Arts Standards: Reading: Foundational Skills: Grade 3. <http://www.corestandards.org/ELA-Literacy/RF/3/>

Teachers can use a variety of resources to support student learning and comprehension of texts. Some possible tools include graphic organizers, such as Venn diagrams and story maps, which can help students identify main ideas, supporting details, and the relationships between them. Teachers can also use digital tools, such as interactive whiteboards and online text annotation tools, to engage students in close reading and encourage them to interact with the text.

In addition to providing explicit instruction on reading comprehension strategies and modeling how to use them, teachers can also encourage students to read widely and develop a love for reading. This can be done by providing access to a variety of high-interest texts, both fiction and nonfiction, and giving students time to read independently and discuss what they have read with their peers.

By providing targeted instruction, resources, and support, teachers can help their students develop strong reading comprehension skills that will serve them well throughout their academic career and beyond.
